hints.content:
The area of $\blue{\text{Rectangle A}}$ can be found by multiplying one side length of $\blue{\text{Rectangle A}}$  by the other side length of $\blue{\text{Rectangle A}}$:   

$\blue{3 \times 5}$ or $\blue{5 \times 3}$.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f6f26c0ada95762cdbe0ed1f8a1e7d2b9a294b2a.png)

The area of $\green{\text{Rectangle B}}$ can be found by multiplying one side length of $\green{\text{Rectangle B}}$  by the other side length of $\green{\text{Rectangle B}}$:   

$\green{3 \times 2}$ or $\green{2 \times 3}$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8329244c76d4e2a4a51e8ec97ac23e24d5f0e964.png)

To find the area of the entire figure, we need to **add** the area of  $\blue{\text{Rectangle A}}$ and the area of $\green{\text{Rectangle B}}$. 
 


![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/63d40d2a5ada901463b75173792c6ff4b1ae8137.png)  


$\blue{3 \times 5} + \green{3 \times 2}$ is equal to the area of the entire figure:


$\begin{align}\blue{3 \times5} + \green{3 \times 2} &= 
\blue{15} + \green{6} \\
\\
&=21.\end{align}$

The multiplication problem that can be used to find the area of the $\blue{\text{Rectangle A}}$ is $\blue{3 \times 5}$ or $\blue{5 \times 3}$.

The multiplication problem that can be used to find the area of the $\green{\text{Rectangle B}}$ is $\green{3 \times 2}$ or $\green{2 \times 3}$.

To find the area of the entire figure, we need to *add* the area of  $\blue{\text{Rectangle A}}$ and the area of $\green{\text{Rectangle B}}$.  

The area of the entire figure is $21$ square units.
